subject: RE: [junit] A Growing Problem
msgSnippet: ... I think your problem is more in the lines of: Having so many methods *in the same class*, not necessarily the fact that you have many methods. Therefore,
messageBody:
> but what if the number of
> test cases grows to 50 or even 500? It seems that there is
> always another test case I should test for. Having this many
> methods becomes unmanageable. The situation gets ugly.

I think your problem is more in the lines of: Having so many methods *in
the same class*, not necessarily the fact that you have many methods.

Therefore, the best option to you is to Refactor. Try moving logically
related test methods to an appropriately named test class. Following
your example earlier:

public class TestCreateBatchLabelNoInnerClass extends TestCase {
public void testNo1 {...} // Of course I would name the test
public void testNo2 {...} // methods more appropriately
...

> This approach suffers from two limitations. The first
> limitation is the need to replicate the test code for every
> test case.

With the approach detailed above, all you need is a bit of cut and paste
(or even better, a good Refactoring tool to do it for you).

> The second limitation is that JUnit will stop the testing
> after the first failure-the remaining test cases won't be executed.

Again, the approach above avoids this problem.
